template:docs/getting-started.title: Quick Start
template:docs/getting-started.text: Quick Start In its simplest form a Printable Page is a document containing chapters. Each chapter defines headers, footers, and one or more sections. Printable Pages will layout your document so that page breaks do not occur in the middle of a section. Header content Some content here Some other content here Footer content Repeating Content Many documents have repeating content. The section component has the ability to iterate over content by passing an array into @data. Item Multiple Columns To render sections over multiple columns use the @columnCount property of a section. Item

template:docs/index.title: Introduction
template:docs/index.text: Introduction Printable Pages aims to make the creation and maintenance of beautiful, paginated documents easy. Features Define your document using the declarative power of handlebars Reuse your existing component Include page headers and footers (impossible to achieve with CSS alone) Define document or chapter title pages Supports multicolumn layouts Easy to test Fast Progressive rendering (users see progress as pages are generated) Makes it easy to provide an in-app preview

template:docs/installation.title: Installation
template:docs/installation.text: Installation To install Ember Printable Pages, run ember install ember-printable-pages

template:docs/limitations.title: Limitations
template:docs/limitations.text: Limitations Browser Print Menus Browsers do not consistently support many css features when printing. This addon provides some sensible defaults which work well in most cases for modern browsers. It is important that the user set margins and scale 'default' in the print menu. This is not controllable via js or css. Sections with lots of text The initial use cases for this addon did not require handling sections with large blocks of text. If the text is larger than a page then the text will overflow the page and be hidden. This use case will get supported eventually. To track progress see Issue #12.

template:docs/rerendering.title: Rerendering
template:docs/rerendering.text: Rerendering If you are building a customizable document or a document which receives regular data updates, then triggering a rerender of the entire document can be necessary. There are a few ways to trigger a full document rerender. Modifying the array passed into @data Changing @columnCount Changing any prop passed into PrintablePages

template:index.title: Motivation
template:index.text: Motivation Creating printable documents from your web app can be infuriatingly hard and either requires unacceptable compromises (no headers or footers) or the use of server side libraries (which have their own limitations). Printable Pages makes it easy. It allows you to create beautiful, printable documents built from your existing components which makes them easy to build, test, customize, and maintain. Printable Provide Printable Pages with your content and it will lay it out across pages, interleaving page headers and footers. In most cases (sorry IE), the browser's print menu can send to printer or create a PDF without trouble. Beautiful By reusing your existing component library, you drive brand consistency between your app and your documents. Product owners and designers rejoice. Delightful No longer do you have to provide your users with 'the report' which comes in one flavor and only makes 80% of your users happy. Instead, create interfaces to customize the document while displaying in-browser preview. Maintainable Gain speed of implementation and lower cost of ownership by building documents from your existing component library. Plus, testing requires no magic. It's just Ember code.
